company.name: X-Mode Social, Inc.
company.business_description: X-Mode is a location data broker that sells consumer location data to hundreds of clients in industries ranging from real estate to finance, as well as private government contractors. X-Mode collects location data through third-party apps that incorporate its software development kit (SDK) and through purchases from other data brokers. X-Mode aggregates and sells this location data to advertisers, software as a service companies, analytics firms, consulting firms, commercial and educational research organizations, and private government contractors.

complaint.factual_background: X-Mode Social, Inc. (later Outlogic) is a location data broker that collected precise consumer location data through SDKs embedded in over 300 mobile apps and sold it to hundreds of clients, including private government contractors. X-Mode sold raw location data and audience segments without removing sensitive location information such as visits to medical facilities, houses of worship, and domestic abuse shelters. From June 2018 to July 2020, X-Mode collected and sold data from consumers who had opted out of personalized advertising on Android devices, directly ignoring their privacy choices. X-Mode's own apps (Drunk Mode and Walk Against Humanity) and the sample disclosures it provided to third-party app publishers failed to inform consumers that their location data would be sold to government contractors for national security purposes. X-Mode also created and sold custom audience segments categorizing consumers based on sensitive health-related characteristics such as visits to cardiology, endocrinology, and gastroenterology offices.

counts.title: Unfair Sale of Sensitive Location Data
counts.representation: Respondents sold, licensed, or otherwise transferred precise location data associated with unique persistent identifiers that reveal consumers' visits to sensitive locations including medical care, reproductive health, religious worship, mental health, temporary shelters, and addiction recovery facilities.
counts.fact: X-Mode's data was not anonymized and could be used to identify individual consumers and track them to sensitive locations, posing risks of discrimination, physical violence, emotional distress, and other serious harms.
counts.conclusion: This practice has caused or is likely to cause substantial injury to consumers that is not outweighed by countervailing benefits and is not reasonably avoidable by consumers themselves. Consequently, this practice is an unfair act or practice.

counts.title: Unfair Failure to Honor Consumer Privacy Choices
counts.representation: Respondents collected and sold location data for developing consumer profiles, surveilling consumers, and targeting them with advertising.
counts.fact: From at least June 2018 to July 2020, X-Mode ingested and sold location data and flags of consumers who had enabled the Android 'Opt out of Ads Personalization' control, directly contrary to those consumers' expressed privacy choices.
counts.conclusion: This practice caused or is likely to cause substantial injury to consumers that is not outweighed by countervailing benefits and is not reasonably avoidable by consumers themselves. Consequently, this practice is an unfair act or practice.

counts.title: Unfair Collection and Use of Consumer Location Data Without Informed Consent
counts.representation: Respondents collected consumers' location data from their own apps (Drunk Mode and Walk Against Humanity) while providing notices purporting to describe how the data would be used.
counts.fact: Until at least August 2020, the notices provided by X-Mode directly to consumers through its own apps failed to fully disclose the purposes for which location data would be used, specifically omitting disclosure of sales to government contractors for national security purposes.
counts.conclusion: This practice has caused or is likely to cause substantial injury to consumers in the form of loss of privacy and increased risk of disclosure of sensitive information. This injury is not outweighed by countervailing benefits and is not reasonably avoidable by consumers. Consequently, this practice is an unfair act or practice.

counts.title: Unfair Collection and Use of Consumer Location Data Without Consent Verification
counts.representation: Respondents collected consumers' location data through third-party apps incorporating their SDK.
counts.fact: X-Mode failed to take reasonable steps to verify that consumers provided informed consent to the collection, use, or sale of their data through those third-party apps. X-Mode was aware that many apps provided deficient notices but failed to require corrections, suspend, or terminate those relationships.
counts.conclusion: This practice has caused or is likely to cause substantial injury to consumers in the form of loss of privacy about the day-to-day movements of millions of consumers and an increased risk of disclosure of sensitive information. Consequently, this practice is an unfair act or practice.

counts.title: Unfair Categorization of Consumers Based on Sensitive Characteristics for Marketing
counts.representation: Respondents created and licensed audience segments — categories of MAIDs based on shared characteristics derived from location data — to third parties.
counts.fact: X-Mode created custom audience segments based on sensitive consumer health characteristics (e.g., visits to cardiology, endocrinology, gastroenterology offices, and specialty infusion centers) and sold these segments to a clinical research company for advertising and marketing purposes.
counts.conclusion: This practice has caused or is likely to cause substantial injury to consumers that is not outweighed by countervailing benefits and is not reasonably avoidable by consumers themselves. Consequently, this practice is an unfair act or practice.

counts.title: Deceptive Failure to Disclose Use of Location Data for Government/National Security Purposes
counts.representation: In numerous instances, Respondents represented, directly or indirectly, that Drunk Mode and Walk Against Humanity app users' location data would be used by third parties for ad personalization and location-based analytics including ad performance, market research, and traffic and health research purposes.
counts.fact: Respondents provided location data collected from those apps to government contractors for national security purposes — a material fact not disclosed to consumers and which would affect their decision to use the apps or grant location permissions.
counts.conclusion: Respondents' failure to disclose this material information, in light of the representations made, is a deceptive act or practice.

counts.title: Means and Instrumentalities to Engage in Deception
counts.representation: Respondents furnished third-party app publishers with recommended language for consumer disclosures in apps and privacy policies describing how consumers' location data would be used.
counts.fact: The sample disclosures provided by X-Mode to third-party app publishers misled consumers about the purposes for which their location data would be used by failing to disclose that consumer location data would be provided to government contractors for national security purposes.
counts.conclusion: By furnishing others with such deceptive materials, Respondents provided the means and instrumentalities for the commission of deceptive acts and practices. Consequently, this practice is a deceptive act or practice.

definitions.Affirmative Express Consent:
any freely given, specific, informed, and unambiguous indication of an individual consumer's wishes demonstrating agreement by the individual, such as by an affirmative action, following a Clear and Conspicuous Disclosure to the individual of: (1) the categories of information that will be collected; (2) the purpose(s) for which the information is being collected, used, or disclosed; (3) the hyperlink to a document that describes the types of entities to whom the Covered Information is disclosed; and (4) the hyperlink to a simple, easily-located means by which the consumer can withdraw consent and that Clearly and Conspicuously describes any limitations on the consumer's ability to withdraw consent. The Clear and Conspicuous Disclosure must be separate from any "privacy policy," "terms of service," "terms of use," or other similar document.

The following does not constitute Affirmative Express Consent:
1. Inferring consent from the hovering over, muting, pausing, or closing of a given piece of content by the consumer; or
2. Obtaining consent through a user interface that has the effect of subverting or impairing user autonomy, decision-making, or choice.
definitions.Clear(ly) and Conspicuous(ly):
that a required disclosure is difficult to miss (i.e., easily noticeable) and easily understandable by ordinary consumers, including in all of the following ways:
1. In any communication that is solely visual or solely audible, the disclosure must be made through the same means through which the communication is presented. In any communication made through both visual and audible means, such as a television advertisement, the disclosure must be presented simultaneously in both the visual and audible portions of the communication even if the representation requiring the disclosure ("triggering representation") is made through only one means.
2. A visual disclosure, by its size, contrast, location, the length of time it appears, and other characteristics, must stand out from any accompanying text or other visual elements so that it is easily noticed, read, and understood.
3. An audible disclosure, including by telephone or streaming video, must be delivered in a volume, speed, and cadence sufficient for ordinary consumers to easily hear and understand it.
4. In any communication using an interactive electronic medium, such as the Internet or software, the disclosure must be unavoidable.
5. The disclosure must use diction and syntax understandable to ordinary consumers and must appear in each language in which the triggering representation appears.
6. The disclosure must comply with these requirements in each medium through which it is received, including all electronic devices and face-to-face communications.
7. The disclosure must not be contradicted or mitigated by, or inconsistent with, anything else in the communication.
8. When the representation or sales practice targets a specific audience, such as children, the elderly, or the terminally ill, "ordinary consumers" includes reasonable members of that group.
definitions.Covered Information: information from or about an individual consumer including, but not limited to: (1) a first and last name; (2) Location Data; (3) an email address or other online contact information; (4) a telephone number; (5) a Social Security number; (6) a driver's license or other government-issued identification number; (7) a financial institution account number; (8) credit or debit card information; (9) a persistent identifier, such as a customer number held in a "cookie," a static Internet Protocol ("IP") address, a mobile device ID, or processor serial number; or (10) socio-economic or demographic data. Deidentified information is not Covered Information.
definitions.Data Product: any model, algorithm or derived data, in Respondents' custody or control developed, in whole or part, using Historic Location Data. Data Product includes but is not limited to any derived data produced via inference (manual or automated) or predictions such as audience segments.
definitions.Deidentified or Deidentifiable: information that cannot reasonably identify, relate to, describe, be capable of being associated with, or be linked, directly or indirectly, to a particular person, in that Respondents must, at a minimum: 1. Have implemented technical safeguards that prohibit reidentification of the person to whom the information may pertain; 2. Have implemented business processes that specifically prohibit reidentification of the information, including by buyers, customers, or other entities to whom Respondents provide the information; 3. Have implemented business processes to prevent inadvertent release of Deidentified information; and 4. Make no attempt to reidentify the information.
definitions.Historic Location Data: any Location Data that Respondents collected from consumers without consumers' Affirmative Express Consent.
definitions.Location Data: any data that may reveal a mobile device's or consumer's precise location, including but not limited to Global Positioning System (GPS) coordinates, cell tower information, or precise location information inferred from basic service set identifiers (BSSIDs), WiFi Service Set Identifiers (SSID) information, or Bluetooth receiver information, and any unique persistent identifier combined with any such data, such as a mobile advertising identifier (MAID) or identifier for advertisers (IDFA). Data that reveals only a mobile device or consumer's coarse location (e.g., zip code or census block location with a radius of at least 1,850 feet) or that is collected outside the United States and used for (a) Security Purposes or (b) National Security purposes conducted by federal agencies or other federal entities is not Location Data.
definitions.National Security: the national defense, foreign intelligence and counterintelligence, international and internal security, and foreign relations. This includes countering terrorism; combating espionage and economic espionage conducted for the benefit of any foreign government, foreign instrumentality, or foreign agent; enforcing export controls and sanctions; and disrupting cyber threats that are perpetrated by nation states, terrorists, or their agents or proxies.
definitions.Raw Format: the format in which Location Data is originally supplied, prior to any form of processing, extraction, or analysis taking place.
definitions.Respondents: X-Mode, Inc. ("X-Mode") and Outlogic, LLC ("Outlogic"), and their successors and assigns.
definitions.Respondents App: a mobile application Respondents own and operate.
definitions.Security Purposes: preventing, detecting, protecting against or responding to security incidents, including cybersecurity incidents, identity theft, fraud, phishing, harassment, malicious or deceptive activities, or preserving the integrity or security of systems.
definitions.Sensitive Locations: locations within the United States associated with: (1) medical facilities (e.g., family planning centers, general medical and surgical hospitals, offices of physicians, offices of mental health physicians and practitioners, residential mental health and substance abuse facilities, outpatient mental health and substance abuse centers, outpatient care centers, psychiatric and substance abuse hospitals, and specialty hospitals); (2) religious organizations; (3) correctional facilities; (4) labor union offices; (5) locations of entities held out to the public as predominantly providing education or childcare services to minors; (6) associations held out to the public as predominantly providing services based on racial or ethnic origin; or (7) locations held out to the public as providing temporary shelter or social services to homeless, survivors of domestic violence, refugees, or immigrants.
definitions.Sensitive Location Data: any consumer Location Data associated with a Sensitive Location.
definitions.Software development kit or SDK: the code necessary to integrate Respondents' advertisements or Location Data collection tools in a mobile application ("app").
definitions.Third-Party Incident: the sharing by a third party of Respondents' Location Data, in violation of a contractual requirement between Respondents and the third party.
